p: Cellulose is a linear biopolymer made up of 7000–15,000 d-glucose monomers which are connected via β-1,4-glycosidic linkages ( Figure 1) [ 42]. Cellulose chains are bonded by van der Waals forces and hydrogen bonds in the microfibrils. In the different cell walls, the arrangement of microfibrils is also different. Microfibrils are combined to form the cellulose fiber [ 38]. Crystalline cellulose appears in the form of crystallinity [ 43]. Degree of polymerization of cellulose is between 1510 and 5500, which strengthens its crystallinity. Moreover, amorphous cellulose is non-organized, which takes up a small proportion. Crystalline cellulose is more resistant to degradation of enzyme compared to amorphous cellulose [ 42, 44].
